JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 16.
HOMEWOOD CONTRACT IS LET
The $68,000 Tunnel Award Goes to Old
Hopkins Man—Walter's New Shop
Said to Be a Spring House.

The contract for the "tunnels"
that are to be used in connection
with the heating, lighting and wiring of the new Homewood buildings was awarded last Wednesday
to the Whiting-Turner Construction Company, whose bid was
$68,000. Gorden Whiting of the
contracting company is a Hopkins
man of the Class of 1900.
The "tunnels" are to serve as
carriers for all heating connections,
wiring, etc., that will be connected
with the power-house. Drawings
for the power-house have been
completed, and specifications are
now being written; so that the entire plans for the heating and electrifying of the buildings at Homewood may be said to be complete.
At this time of the year, when
there is nothing in the line of athletics to attract the students, they
lose sight of the progress being
made at Homewood.
Gilman Hall, the library building, is rapidly nearing completion.
The plastering of the walls and
the cementing of the floors is now
about finished, as the. building, has
been under cover since last November. The slate roof is also nearly
laid. Gilman Hall will be ready
for occupancy June 1, but will not
be used until the following year.
The Mechanical and Electrical
Engineering Laboratory has less
than one story and a dormer yet to
be built, which means that the
building will be under cover some
time in March. The steel work and
skylight radiators connected with
Machinery Hall are completed and
this portion of the building soon
will be enclosed.
The steel work for the amphitheatre has also been constructed.
The lecture-room is situated in the
center of the building and will have
a seating capacity of about 200.
Architect Sperry reports that the
shops will be ready on June I, as
per contract; the building proper,
August 1.
Plans for the oval garden on
Charles street are still "in the air."
Although suggestions have been
made several times as to what
should be put in this garden, no
definite action has as yet been taken.
There are many advocates for a
monument to Edgar Allan Poe to
be erected on this oval.

unforeseen error, Walter, the Portuguese barber, who occupies a suite

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 16, 1914.

HOPKINS RELAY TEAM BREAKS RECORD
Senior Team Wins From the University of Virginia, Bettering Their
Former Record by One-Fifth of a Second—Two World's
Records Broken—Wagner 100-Yd. S. A. A. U.
Champion—Va. Wins Team Trophy.
Hopkins track artists shared in the breaking of records in the Johns
Hopkins-Fifth Regiment indoor track and field games, held last Saturday
night in the Armory, when the senior team, running against Virginia, their
old track rivals, bettered their owni record for the mile relay race. Two
world records were also toppled.
The Hopkins-Virginia race was just such a race as that run last year
between these two teams, at which time the Black and Blue runners broke
-the record. Captain H. Milton Wagner was the first man on the Hopkins team and ran a good race; Herbert Catlin and Claude Uhler ran
next in order, and Huntley Lloyd ran last. Both teams were about even
when Lloyd started, Virginia having the advantage if anything, owing
to the fact that she had the inside. The desires of the Hopkins rooters,
crowded in the gallery just above the finish, were now fulfilled, and no
doubt they were a bit confident that the race was theirs, for they felt sure
that if Lloyd could get an even start with his man he would break the
tape. Such was the case. Huntley romped home fifteen yards ahead of
his man, making the distance in the wonderful time of 3 minutes 52 seconds.
J. H. Crowley, sporting Virginia colors, carried back with him a world's
record for the ioo-yard low hurdles. The holder of the record for the
220-yard South Atlantic Collegiate dash was in fine form and made the
distance in 3% seconds, bettering Egan Geller's former record by onefifth second. "Toni" McDonagh, running unattached, and Jennis Galloway, of the Cross Country Club, finished in the order named.
The second world's record was shattered when Company K won the
wall-scaling event in 40 seconds. This record will likely stand a while
as it is seven seconds better than the former one, made in Seattle, Wash.
Company K far outclassed the other teams, the next best time being 57
seconds, made by Company A.
The next important event in the eyes of the Hopkins followers is the
relay race between the junior Black and Blue team, Catholic University
and Maryland Agricultural College. The teams finished in the order
named, but the distances apart at the finish was more noticeable than it
is here. Stiebel, running last for the Black and Blue team, broke the
tape about fifty yards ahead of the Catholic University runner. Groover,
Gayley and Wells were the other men on the team each gaining about
ten yards.
The relay race between Hopkins and Georgetown freshmen was one
of the hair-raising events of the evening and resulted in a victory for
the Black and Blue men. Straus, Sutton, Fred Hall and Binford ran
in order. The two teams ran a neck-to-neck race until the last lap, when
Binford made a fine spurt, and crossed the line fifteen yards in the lead.
An idea of the calibre of athletes who roam about the country where
"Cliff" Wells hails from, was given when the much-talked of Canadian
relay team beat the Carlisle Indians in a mile race, making the distance
in 3 minutes 27/5 seconds. The Toronto runners realized after they
arrived here that the Indians were not in their class and gave them a
liberal handicap to make things interesting. The Indians ran a good race
and fought hard to keep in the lead. "Jack" Tait ran a very fast quarter
and passed John Plenty (who did not have enough) on the last lap and
NV011 amid cheers.
The ioo-yard South Atlantic Amateur Athletic Union Championship
dash was won by Bod Wagner, of Hopkins. Owing to the fact that a
number of the Northern entrants were ruled out of the Southern Championship contests, there were no heats. Bod's time was 1075 seconds,
leading Brewer, of Georgetown, by a good three yards. Hartung, of
the Harrier's Club, was a good third.
City College was far outclassed by the Polytechnic runners. In both
the senior and junior relay races the Engineers defeated their old rivals.
The Collegians showed lack of training and poor judgment on the curves.
The race between the senior teams was very exciting and until the last
lap it looked as if the runners with the "noisy" pants would win out.
Shipman,"Poly's" fast little quarter-miler, started out fifteen yards behind

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
A FEW SIDELIGHTS ON THE MEET
Some Facts and Frivolities That Interested and Amused at the Games.
Sutton Facile Grammarian.

"Ben" Tappan was the "open"
hero of the meet. \Vhen Scorer
Blanck tabulated the standing in
points of the open events, Johns
Hopkins stood third with six tallies. Tappan made them all, but
he was not victor in any race. He
tied with Low, of Georgetown, for
first in the high jump, and was
third in the pole-vault. Hence, any
rooters who feel proud of the standing:
Virginia
21 points,
Georgetown
12 points,
Hopkins
6 points,
must thank "Ben" Tappan.
The band, huddled together within six square feet of the great floor
expanse, did nobly, but was not appreciated in all quarters. Especially
was this true when it somewhat derisively played "Get Out and Get
Under" during the mile run.
Captain Wagner, the new South
Atlantic century champion, if you
. please, loped the distance to fame
in admirable fashion. Indeed, a
young lady in the east gallery quite
admiringly remarked:
"Oh, such a gait! He looks like
the bisque statue of 'Mercury' we
have in the parlor."
But such is fame, Bod.
It is conceivable that the many
disqualifications which marked the
meet would not have occurred had
Referee Burdick instructed and disciplined his assisting officials more
carefully. The fact that only one
man ill the 220-yard dash (open)
receiver a medal, all others being
disqualified, shows that there was
marked looseness in the official
staff. Then, too, had Mike Thompson been referee. the meet would
have started promptly.
Walter D. Sutton, whose ability
as an announcer was positively established at the meet, has evidently
lost his note books covering English composition and grammar
courses. He was guilty of the following, yelled to the east gallery
in volcanic tone:
"The Toronto-Carlisle relay race
will be ran next!"
Company K, world's champion
wall scalers, were "makers and
breakers of men." When the "wall"
was pushed out on the floor somebody in the east gallery suggested
"laying a little bet" on the various
competing companies.
The system of tabulating the results on small pads at the finish,
sending them to the scorer and then
to the press tables, worked without
a flaw.

ENGINEERING SOCIETY MEETING
Dr. Gilpin Lectures in a Most Instructive
Manner on "The Place of Chemistry in Engineering."

Dr. Gilpin's lecture on "The Place
of Chemistry in Engineering" was
well received by members of the
Engineering Society last Monday.
It was the general opinion that the
lecture was the most interesting
and instructive that the Society has
heard for quite a time.
The speaker began by stating
that his position was that of the
true chemist, rather than the chemical engineer, but that he had, nevertheless, clearly seen the advantages
of a thorough knowledge of the
principles of chemistry to the engineer.
Dr. Gilpin then performed several experiments, the result of
which the chemist had known for
a long time, but he said that it had
remained for the engineer to work
out the practical advantages of this
result. Slides were shown which
illustrated the applications of these
principles in the industrial world of
today.
Three of the things which Dr.
Gilpin illustrated and spoke of at
length were the oxy-hydrogen blowpipe, the Goldschmidt thermite process for the reduction of oxides
and the attainment of high temperatures, and the application of finely
divided platinum as a catalytic

ILI (2-)

agent in the preparation of sulphuric acid.
The lecturer concluded with some
remarks for the benefit of the members, dwelling at length on the desirability of obtaining a broad general education while in college.
The next meeting of the Society
will probably be held on Monday,
March 2, although no speaker has
been definitely engaged for that date.

Congratulations to the Track Team.

Hopkins cinderpath artists accomplished their fondest hopes in
the Johns Hopkins-Fifth Regiment
indoor track and field games on
Saturday evening. The three relay
teams, sporting Black and Blue
colors, won their races in a manner
the memory of which will linger
in the minds of the rooters for some
time.
The 'Varsity team, composed of
Captain H. Milton Wagner, Herbert Catlin, Claude Uhler and Huntley Lloyd, won from the University of Virginia quartet in the record time of 3 minutes 35 seconds.
All of these men are to be congratulated on the brilliant performance.
. Not less deserving are the members of the junior and freshmen.
team. Both showed the true Hopkins spirit, and although hard
pressed at first, won by a considerable margin.
The man responsible for this excellent showing of the Black and
Blue teams is Coach Joseph England.- His untiring efforts with
the squad proved to be not without
success. . Even Mr. England himself was overjoyed with the result
of the races, as was shown by his
jumping-jack performance on the
side of the track, when Lloyd was

Movement? What does it mean to
China that Confucianism has been
adopted as the state religion? What
really is the Yellow Peril? Such
questions as these are being talked
of daily by intelligent men. Can
you discuss them intelligently?
In this age of specialization tending to narrow one's interests to his
own particular study, we hear many
cries for a greater dispersion of our
endeavor. The conditions of a college life and the limitations of a
college curriculum are necessarily
such that the mind of the average
student is not occupied with the
conditions surrounding remote nations of the earth and the great
currents of life that move among
them. He thinks in terms of his
fraternity, of his team, of his class,
of his college work and of the immediate problems of his own life.
A consideration of the problems
of other lands brings him a breadth
of outlook. Every man who would
be a well-rounded man in this day
of world interests must know something of these other lands. The
sole place where the undergraduate
can learn anything of the great,

Advice to the Seniors.

When a freshman comes up to
college it is quite the tradition to
overwhelm him with good advice
which you know he will never follow. When a man becomes a sophomore you know how futile it is
even to attempt to make him listen
to advice, and then when he is a
junior—well, then he's an upperclass man. And so it comes about
that sometimes a man actually gets
to be a senior without getting, or
at least taking, any advice.
We believe, however, that there
are a number of men in our senior
class, fine though it is, who might
profit by a little hint here and there
in several lines, and so we are going to risk printing here a few of
them in the hope that they may be
of benefit.
First, pay your class dues. It
would be hard to overestimate the
importance of this when so much
remains to be done in the next two
or three months. Don't make the
treasurer continually ask you.
If you have not already done so,
go to Jeffries and have your picture
taken at once for the "Hullabaloo."
Every day that you put it off is
only causing your class-mates on
the Hullabaloo Board that much
more worry and delay.

$100 Prize for Civic Essay.

The following letter was received
last week by Registrar Thomas R.
Ball:
The Intercollegiate Civic League
wishes to inform you that a prize
of $,Ioo has been offered by a member of its Executive Committee for
the best essay on the following subject:
"What training, whether resulting from a college course of study,
from extra-curricular activities, or
from both, would in your judgment
best fit an undergraduate in an
American college to undertake upon
graduation the duties of citizenship?"
The competition will be open to
undergraduates in any American
college or university.
The essays must be typewritten
in duplicate and in the hands of the
Secretary of the Intercollegiate
Civic League not later than May
15, 1914.
They may not exceed 5,000 words
in length.
The Hon. Seth Low and the
Hon. Robert L. Owen, senator
from Oklahoma, have consented to
act as the judges.
einy questions regarding this
competition should be addressed to
Secretary,
E. M. SAIT,
Columbia University,
New York City.

Getz Gets After The News-Letter, but
Everyone's on Our Side.

FEBRUARY

14, 1914.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—In regard to the article
in the last issue of THE NEWSLETTER, headed "Hopkins Has a
Carrie Nation," I, as business manager of the "Hullabaloo," • would
like to call your attention to the
following facts:
Either THE NEWS-LETTER reporter who was assigned to the
story is a most imaginative and artful youth, or there was a wish to
publish a wilfully false and garbled
report concerning the "Hullabaloo's" advertising wall and the putting thereon of certain beer signs
by parties unknown, although THE
NEWS-LETTER'S sleuths are still on
the "case," (of what?).
The falsity of the entire article
is demonstrated by the fact that I
never saw the said signs—either
when they were on the wall, or
when they were broken. Consequently, the imaginative reporter
slipped one over and wilfully lowered the standard of THE NEWSLETTER'S columns by publishing
news that he knew to be false. I
leave it to the University to decide
which horn of the dilemma is most
pleasant.
Very truly yours,
LAWRENCE GETZ,
Business Manager of the 1914
"Hullabaloo."

selections from grand opera, the
finale being the Tannhauser "Pilgrim Chorus," sung to the tune of
"He Had to Get Under.- To permit the divine harmony to sink in

After the vaudeville came the

The "eats" were just about as good

On the whole, the blow-out was

went through it in that spirit of
insouciance and devil-may-careness
which comes with experience and
old age. Yours truly,
A SENIOR.

Grotius Society Active.

At the last meeting of the Grotius Society, two important announcements were made.
The Peace Contest Committee
first reported that the annual Statewide contest wonld take place in
McCoy Hall on the night of Friday, March 27, and that the Maryland Peace Society would very
likely again donate the money for
two prizes, the first of $75, and
the second of $50.
Representatives from about five
or six of the State colleges will
compete in this contest. The names
of the judges will be announced
later. Try-outs for the position of
Hopkins representative will be held
during the first week of March..
The committee which is arranging for the debate between the Grotius and the Zelosophic Society of
of the University of Pennsylvania,
announced that the contest would
be held in Philadelphia during the
latter part of April, probably on
the 24th or 25th. Last year the
debate was held in this city.
The Zelosophics will shortly send
a subject to the local Society, which
will choose the side it will defend,
and then hold a try-out for positions on the team. The team will
consist of three speakers, an alternate and an adviser.

The Hopkins "J.O.L." at the "Blow-out."
FEBRUARY 14, 1914.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—The annual football
blow-out—that time-honored, wellworn affair that took place in the
gymnasium last Tuesday—was attended by a small but almost enthusiastic audience, composed chiefly of bored seniors and interested
freshmen.
The affair was called to order by
"Butts" Sutton, the president of the
Athletic Association, who introduced the chief "speakers" of the
evening—Harvey Stone and "Joe"
England. These two Hopkins
alumni told the same old story of
Hopkins spirit, of last year's successful records, and of the promising hopes for a better showing this
season. Then Coach Wolfe, of the
lacrosse team, acting as substitute
for Pitts Raleigh, who was absent
from the meeting for some unexplainable reason, urged more new
men to come out for the team.
The real treat of the evening,
however, was the concert rendered
by a dusky quartet of Chester's
acquaintances. The repertoire of
these accomplished ear-drum splitters contained such well known
favorites as "Nigger, Roll 'em
Bones!" "Way Down Yonder in
the Cornfield," as well as choral

BALTIMORE

Wednesday, February 25

Under the leadership of A. K.
Barton, '14, the freshmen held their
first meeting last Thursday at io
A. M. About forty students were
on hand to begin the study of
"The Emergency in China." W. D.
("Butts")Sutton, 'ht., will be leader
of the class this week.
The juniors met for the first time
on Tuesday at i P. M. H. M.
Wagner, '12, who will conduct the
class, presented important points
that are to be studied in connection with the topic, "The Moslem
World."
The sophomores and seniors held
organization meetings at the same
time,. and will start detailed study
this week.

Chess Match Postponed.

The chess match between Hopkins and Georgetown, which was
scheduled for last Thursday night,
ha's been postponed until Thursday,
February 26, on which date tne
contest will be held in the rooms of
the Baltimore Chess Club on North
Eutaw street, at eight o'clock.
Although the team which will
represent the University has not
yet been definitely picked, Captain
Hammond recently announced that
it would probably consist of Bolling and Brown of the graduate
department, and Hammond, Davis,
Melamet and Chenoweth, undergraduates.
The annual tournament between
the members of the local club is
rapidly drawing to an end. Play
is being held daily in Levering Hall.
At present, Melamet is leading,
with seven victories and two defeats.

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 16.
HOMEWOOD CONTRACT IS LET
The $68,000 Tunnel Award Goes to Old
Hopkins Man—Walter's New Shop
Said to Be a Spring House.

The contract for the "tunnels"
that are to be used in connection
with the heating, lighting and wiring of the new Homewood buildings was awarded last Wednesday
to the Whiting-Turner Construction Company, whose bid was
$68,000. Gorden Whiting of the
contracting company is a Hopkins
man of the Class of 1900.
The "tunnels" are to serve as
carriers for all heating connections,
wiring, etc., that will be connected
with the power-house. Drawings
for the power-house have been
completed, and specifications are
now being written; so that the entire plans for the heating and electrifying of the buildings at Homewood may be said to be complete.
At this time of the year, when
there is nothing in the line of athletics to attract the students, they
lose sight of the progress being
made at Homewood.
Gilman Hall, the library building, is rapidly nearing completion.
The plastering of the walls and
the cementing of the floors is now
about finished, as the. building, has
been under cover since last November. The slate roof is also nearly
laid. Gilman Hall will be ready
for occupancy June 1, but will not
be used until the following year.
The Mechanical and Electrical
Engineering Laboratory has less
than one story and a dormer yet to
be built, which means that the
building will be under cover some
time in March. The steel work and
skylight radiators connected with
Machinery Hall are completed and
this portion of the building soon
will be enclosed.
The steel work for the amphitheatre has also been constructed.
The lecture-room is situated in the
center of the building and will have
a seating capacity of about 200.
Architect Sperry reports that the
shops will be ready on June I, as
per contract; the building proper,
August 1.
Plans for the oval garden on
Charles street are still "in the air."
Although suggestions have been
made several times as to what
should be put in this garden, no
definite action has as yet been taken.
There are many advocates for a
monument to Edgar Allan Poe to
be erected on this oval.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 16, 1914.

HOPKINS RELAY TEAM BREAKS RECORD
Senior Team Wins From the University of Virginia, Bettering Their
Former Record by One-Fifth of a Second—Two World's
Records Broken—Wagner 100-Yd. S. A. A. U.
Champion—Va. Wins Team Trophy.
Hopkins track artists shared in the breaking of records in the Johns
Hopkins-Fifth Regiment indoor track and field games, held last Saturday
night in the Armory, when the senior team, running against Virginia, their
old track rivals, bettered their owni record for the mile relay race. Two
world records were also toppled.
The Hopkins-Virginia race was just such a race as that run last year
between these two teams, at which time the Black and Blue runners broke
-the record. Captain H. Milton Wagner was the first man on the Hopkins team and ran a good race; Herbert Catlin and Claude Uhler ran
next in order, and Huntley Lloyd ran last. Both teams were about even
when Lloyd started, Virginia having the advantage if anything, owing
to the fact that she had the inside. The desires of the Hopkins rooters,
crowded in the gallery just above the finish, were now fulfilled, and no
doubt they were a bit confident that the race was theirs, for they felt sure
that if Lloyd could get an even start with his man he would break the
tape. Such was the case. Huntley romped home fifteen yards ahead of
his man, making the distance in the wonderful time of 3 minutes 52 seconds.
J. H. Crowley, sporting Virginia colors, carried back with him a world's
record for the ioo-yard low hurdles. The holder of the record for the
220-yard South Atlantic Collegiate dash was in fine form and made the
distance in 3% seconds, bettering Egan Geller's former record by onefifth second. "Toni" McDonagh, running unattached, and Jennis Galloway, of the Cross Country Club, finished in the order named.
The second world's record was shattered when Company K won the
wall-scaling event in 40 seconds. This record will likely stand a while
as it is seven seconds better than the former one, made in Seattle, Wash.
Company K far outclassed the other teams, the next best time being 57
seconds, made by Company A.
The next important event in the eyes of the Hopkins followers is the
relay race between the junior Black and Blue team, Catholic University
and Maryland Agricultural College. The teams finished in the order
named, but the distances apart at the finish was more noticeable than it
is here. Stiebel, running last for the Black and Blue team, broke the
tape about fifty yards ahead of the Catholic University runner. Groover,
Gayley and Wells were the other men on the team each gaining about
ten yards.
The relay race between Hopkins and Georgetown freshmen was one
of the hair-raising events of the evening and resulted in a victory for
the Black and Blue men. Straus, Sutton, Fred Hall and Binford ran
in order. The two teams ran a neck-to-neck race until the last lap, when
Binford made a fine spurt, and crossed the line fifteen yards in the lead.
An idea of the calibre of athletes who roam about the country where
"Cliff" Wells hails from, was given when the much-talked of Canadian
relay team beat the Carlisle Indians in a mile race, making the distance
in 3 minutes 27/5 seconds. The Toronto runners realized after they
arrived here that the Indians were not in their class and gave them a
liberal handicap to make things interesting. The Indians ran a good race
and fought hard to keep in the lead. "Jack" Tait ran a very fast quarter
and passed John Plenty (who did not have enough) on the last lap and
NV011 amid cheers.
The ioo-yard South Atlantic Amateur Athletic Union Championship
dash was won by Bod Wagner, of Hopkins. Owing to the fact that a
number of the Northern entrants were ruled out of the Southern Championship contests, there were no heats. Bod's time was 1075 seconds,
leading Brewer, of Georgetown, by a good three yards. Hartung, of
the Harrier's Club, was a good third.
City College was far outclassed by the Polytechnic runners. In both
the senior and junior relay races the Engineers defeated their old rivals.
The Collegians showed lack of training and poor judgment on the curves.
The race between the senior teams was very exciting and until the last
lap it looked as if the runners with the "noisy" pants would win out.
Shipman,"Poly's" fast little quarter-miler, started out fifteen yards behind

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
A FEW SIDELIGHTS ON THE MEET
Some Facts and Frivolities That Interested and Amused at the Games.
Sutton Facile Grammarian.

"Ben" Tappan was the "open"
hero of the meet. \Vhen Scorer
Blanck tabulated the standing in
points of the open events, Johns
Hopkins stood third with six tallies. Tappan made them all, but
he was not victor in any race. He
tied with Low, of Georgetown, for
first in the high jump, and was
third in the pole-vault. Hence, any
rooters who feel proud of the standing:
Virginia
21 points,
Georgetown
12 points,
Hopkins
6 points,
must thank "Ben" Tappan.
The band, huddled together within six square feet of the great floor
expanse, did nobly, but was not appreciated in all quarters. Especially
was this true when it somewhat derisively played "Get Out and Get
Under" during the mile run.
Captain Wagner, the new South
Atlantic century champion, if you
. please, loped the distance to fame
in admirable fashion. Indeed, a
young lady in the east gallery quite
admiringly remarked:
"Oh, such a gait! He looks like
the bisque statue of 'Mercury' we
have in the parlor."
But such is fame, Bod.
It is conceivable that the many
disqualifications which marked the
meet would not have occurred had
Referee Burdick instructed and disciplined his assisting officials more
carefully. The fact that only one
man ill the 220-yard dash (open)
receiver a medal, all others being
disqualified, shows that there was
marked looseness in the official
staff. Then, too, had Mike Thompson been referee. the meet would
have started promptly.
Walter D. Sutton, whose ability
as an announcer was positively established at the meet, has evidently
lost his note books covering English composition and grammar
courses. He was guilty of the following, yelled to the east gallery
in volcanic tone:
"The Toronto-Carlisle relay race
will be ran next!"
Company K, world's champion
wall scalers, were "makers and
breakers of men." When the "wall"
was pushed out on the floor somebody in the east gallery suggested
"laying a little bet" on the various
competing companies.
The system of tabulating the results on small pads at the finish,
sending them to the scorer and then
to the press tables, worked without
a flaw.

ENGINEERING SOCIETY MEETING
Dr. Gilpin Lectures in a Most Instructive
Manner on "The Place of Chemistry in Engineering."

Dr. Gilpin's lecture on "The Place
of Chemistry in Engineering" was
well received by members of the
Engineering Society last Monday.
It was the general opinion that the
lecture was the most interesting
and instructive that the Society has
heard for quite a time.
The speaker began by stating
that his position was that of the
true chemist, rather than the chemical engineer, but that he had, nevertheless, clearly seen the advantages
of a thorough knowledge of the
principles of chemistry to the engineer.
Dr. Gilpin then performed several experiments, the result of
which the chemist had known for
a long time, but he said that it had
remained for the engineer to work
out the practical advantages of this
result. Slides were shown which
illustrated the applications of these
principles in the industrial world of
today.
Three of the things which Dr.
Gilpin illustrated and spoke of at
length were the oxy-hydrogen blowpipe, the Goldschmidt thermite process for the reduction of oxides
and the attainment of high temperatures, and the application of finely
divided platinum as a catalytic

ILI (2-)

agent in the preparation of sulphuric acid.
The lecturer concluded with some
remarks for the benefit of the members, dwelling at length on the desirability of obtaining a broad general education while in college.
The next meeting of the Society
will probably be held on Monday,
March 2, although no speaker has
been definitely engaged for that date.

Congratulations to the Track Team.

Hopkins cinderpath artists accomplished their fondest hopes in
the Johns Hopkins-Fifth Regiment
indoor track and field games on
Saturday evening. The three relay
teams, sporting Black and Blue
colors, won their races in a manner
the memory of which will linger
in the minds of the rooters for some
time.
The 'Varsity team, composed of
Captain H. Milton Wagner, Herbert Catlin, Claude Uhler and Huntley Lloyd, won from the University of Virginia quartet in the record time of 3 minutes 35 seconds.
All of these men are to be congratulated on the brilliant performance.
. Not less deserving are the members of the junior and freshmen.
team. Both showed the true Hopkins spirit, and although hard
pressed at first, won by a considerable margin.
The man responsible for this excellent showing of the Black and
Blue teams is Coach Joseph England.- His untiring efforts with
the squad proved to be not without
success. . Even Mr. England himself was overjoyed with the result
of the races, as was shown by his
jumping-jack performance on the
side of the track, when Lloyd was

Movement? What does it mean to
China that Confucianism has been
adopted as the state religion? What
really is the Yellow Peril? Such
questions as these are being talked
of daily by intelligent men. Can
you discuss them intelligently?
In this age of specialization tending to narrow one's interests to his
own particular study, we hear many
cries for a greater dispersion of our
endeavor. The conditions of a college life and the limitations of a
college curriculum are necessarily
such that the mind of the average
student is not occupied with the
conditions surrounding remote nations of the earth and the great
currents of life that move among
them. He thinks in terms of his
fraternity, of his team, of his class,
of his college work and of the immediate problems of his own life.
A consideration of the problems
of other lands brings him a breadth
of outlook. Every man who would
be a well-rounded man in this day
of world interests must know something of these other lands. The
sole place where the undergraduate
can learn anything of the great,
newly-awakened countries is the
mission study class. If only for
their educational value, a man
should attend one of the classes.

Advice to the Seniors.

When a freshman comes up to
college it is quite the tradition to
overwhelm him with good advice
which you know he will never follow. When a man becomes a sophomore you know how futile it is
even to attempt to make him listen
to advice, and then when he is a
junior—well, then he's an upperclass man. And so it comes about
that sometimes a man actually gets
to be a senior without getting, or
at least taking, any advice.
We believe, however, that there
are a number of men in our senior
class, fine though it is, who might
profit by a little hint here and there
in several lines, and so we are going to risk printing here a few of
them in the hope that they may be
of benefit.
First, pay your class dues. It
would be hard to overestimate the
importance of this when so much
remains to be done in the next two
or three months. Don't make the
treasurer continually ask you.
If you have not already done so,
go to Jeffries and have your picture
taken at once for the "Hullabaloo."
Every day that you put it off is
only causing your class-mates on
the Hullabaloo Board that much
more worry and delay.

$100 Prize for Civic Essay.

The following letter was received
last week by Registrar Thomas R.
Ball:
The Intercollegiate Civic League
wishes to inform you that a prize
of $,Ioo has been offered by a member of its Executive Committee for
the best essay on the following subject:
"What training, whether resulting from a college course of study,
from extra-curricular activities, or
from both, would in your judgment
best fit an undergraduate in an
American college to undertake upon
graduation the duties of citizenship?"
The competition will be open to
undergraduates in any American
college or university.
The essays must be typewritten
in duplicate and in the hands of the
Secretary of the Intercollegiate
Civic League not later than May
15, 1914.
They may not exceed 5,000 words
in length.
The Hon. Seth Low and the
Hon. Robert L. Owen, senator
from Oklahoma, have consented to
act as the judges.
einy questions regarding this
competition should be addressed to
Secretary,
E. M. SAIT,
Columbia University,
New York City.

Getz Gets After The News-Letter, but
Everyone's on Our Side.

FEBRUARY

14, 1914.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—In regard to the article
in the last issue of THE NEWSLETTER, headed "Hopkins Has a
Carrie Nation," I, as business manager of the "Hullabaloo," • would
like to call your attention to the
following facts:
Either THE NEWS-LETTER reporter who was assigned to the
story is a most imaginative and artful youth, or there was a wish to
publish a wilfully false and garbled
report concerning the "Hullabaloo's" advertising wall and the putting thereon of certain beer signs
by parties unknown, although THE
NEWS-LETTER'S sleuths are still on
the "case," (of what?).
The falsity of the entire article
is demonstrated by the fact that I
never saw the said signs—either
when they were on the wall, or
when they were broken. Consequently, the imaginative reporter
slipped one over and wilfully lowered the standard of THE NEWSLETTER'S columns by publishing
news that he knew to be false. I
leave it to the University to decide
which horn of the dilemma is most
pleasant.
Very truly yours,
LAWRENCE GETZ,
Business Manager of the 1914
"Hullabaloo."

Grotius Society Active.

At the last meeting of the Grotius Society, two important announcements were made.
The Peace Contest Committee
first reported that the annual Statewide contest wonld take place in
McCoy Hall on the night of Friday, March 27, and that the Maryland Peace Society would very
likely again donate the money for
two prizes, the first of $75, and
the second of $50.
Representatives from about five
or six of the State colleges will
compete in this contest. The names
of the judges will be announced
later. Try-outs for the position of
Hopkins representative will be held
during the first week of March..
The committee which is arranging for the debate between the Grotius and the Zelosophic Society of
of the University of Pennsylvania,
announced that the contest would
be held in Philadelphia during the
latter part of April, probably on
the 24th or 25th. Last year the
debate was held in this city.
The Zelosophics will shortly send
a subject to the local Society, which
will choose the side it will defend,
and then hold a try-out for positions on the team. The team will
consist of three speakers, an alternate and an adviser.

The Hopkins "J.O.L." at the "Blow-out."
FEBRUARY 14, 1914.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—The annual football
blow-out—that time-honored, wellworn affair that took place in the
gymnasium last Tuesday—was attended by a small but almost enthusiastic audience, composed chiefly of bored seniors and interested
freshmen.
The affair was called to order by
"Butts" Sutton, the president of the
Athletic Association, who introduced the chief "speakers" of the
evening—Harvey Stone and "Joe"
England. These two Hopkins
alumni told the same old story of
Hopkins spirit, of last year's successful records, and of the promising hopes for a better showing this
season. Then Coach Wolfe, of the
lacrosse team, acting as substitute
for Pitts Raleigh, who was absent
from the meeting for some unexplainable reason, urged more new
men to come out for the team.
The real treat of the evening,
however, was the concert rendered
by a dusky quartet of Chester's
acquaintances. The repertoire of
these accomplished ear-drum splitters contained such well known
favorites as "Nigger, Roll 'em
Bones!" "Way Down Yonder in
the Cornfield," as well as choral

BALTIMORE

Wednesday, February 25

Under the leadership of A. K.
Barton, '14, the freshmen held their
first meeting last Thursday at io
A. M. About forty students were
on hand to begin the study of
"The Emergency in China." W. D.
("Butts")Sutton, 'ht., will be leader
of the class this week.
The juniors met for the first time
on Tuesday at i P. M. H. M.
Wagner, '12, who will conduct the
class, presented important points
that are to be studied in connection with the topic, "The Moslem
World."
The sophomores and seniors held
organization meetings at the same
time,. and will start detailed study
this week.

Chess Match Postponed.

The chess match between Hopkins and Georgetown, which was
scheduled for last Thursday night,
ha's been postponed until Thursday,
February 26, on which date tne
contest will be held in the rooms of
the Baltimore Chess Club on North
Eutaw street, at eight o'clock.
Although the team which will
represent the University has not
yet been definitely picked, Captain
Hammond recently announced that
it would probably consist of Bolling and Brown of the graduate
department, and Hammond, Davis,
Melamet and Chenoweth, undergraduates.
The annual tournament between
the members of the local club is
rapidly drawing to an end. Play
is being held daily in Levering Hall.
At present, Melamet is leading,
with seven victories and two defeats.

Cronin, who ran last for City College, but on the last lap passed his man

the Polytechnic track artists.
In the field events Hopkins entrants made a creditable showing, considering that the Black and Blue squad is weakest in these events. "Ben"
Tappan tied for first place with Low, of Georgetown, with the bar at
5 feet 93
/
4. inches. Tappan also placed in the pole-vault, getting third
place. Weidman, of Georgetown, and Robertson, his teammate, were
first and second, respectively, in this event, the .winner's height being
ii feet ig inches.
In the shot-put, Barker, of Virginia, beat out Coleman, also of Virginia,
by a few inches. Sturgis, of Hopkins, was third. Barker put the sphere
44 feet 272 inches and had a handicap of i foot 6 inches.
